title: Both the IV and V chords sound dominant to me. What are some tips to distinguish them in chord progressions? - Quora

response.answer_text: I know the problem. I had it too. I’m going to assume that you know the difference between the IV and the V as was also the case with me. I studied music theory and although I knew all of the pertinent theory behind these chords and plenty more I often seemed to not hear when a dominant chord was dominant and I mixed them up with Sub-Dominant chords. Needless to say this was embarrassing! This wasn’t to do with a lack of understanding with what these chords were and what function they played. This was less the case when the Dominant chord was diminished or at least had a b9. The closer a dominant chord got to a diminished vii chord the easier it got. Nonetheless, the dominant triad was sometimes mixed up in my hearing with the IV triad. My solution came with practice of playing what I hear by ear. Ie. listening to pop songs or film music (not so much ‘normal’ classical music or even modern classical music and also not so much jazz) and playing back what I heard and comparing. For me the solution was just in practice - trial and error. Eventually I started to hear the falling fifth (or rising fourth) of the root for the IV and the rising fifth (or falling fourth) for the V chord. I talked about my difficulty in hearing the difference with my professor at the time and he wasn’t really able to give me much help - I found that the difficulty wasn’t a matter of missing understanding, but rather just one of missing practice. I hear ‘absolute’. Ie if you play a note on the piano or any instrument for that matter I can tell you directly what it is (granted my accuracy with the voice is sometimes more like 90% - also, this only works 70% of the time the other way around, ie when I have to deliver a ‘C’ from my own voice). So maybe I only hear ‘kind-of-absolute’. The relevance of this is that you might also hear absolute. I find/have found, that some absolute listeners are sometimes somewhat crippled by their absolute hearing. This was definitely the case with me and it is still an issue sometimes. Sometimes they completely forgo their ability to hear ‘relative’ (ie. to hear the relationships between chords). Instead, single tones are heard and their relationships are ignored. If you hear absolute it’s important to do your best to forbid yourself of listening to the individual tones of the chord and force yourself to try and listen to the chord as a whole and it’s relationship to the neighbouring chords. It is possible with practice. Hearing ‘relative’ needs to be practiced and developed. If you had not been doing this yet, or just to a minimal degree then you have some catching up to do (as did I). I suggest doing simple ‘listen’ and ‘play-what-you-hear’ for many songs. Simple is always good and pop music is quite helpful here. Pop will have a lot of IV and V - granted there will also be plenty of iii and vi - but hey, c’est la vie! Do NOT use lead sheet or chord charts. I assume you know all of your 12 major and 12 minor chords, if not learn them. With the guitar you can do this with a handful of Barre chords. If you want have a look here: How do guitar players play the same chord up and down the guitar (I’m coming from a piano background)? You can also alternatively use a capo, but I’d recommend learning how to get around the aforementioned 24 chords without a capo as well. Start with some Bronze Radio Return (Further On), Coldplay (there are occasional modulations [generally the relative minor], but they are nonetheless pretty overwhelmingly I IV V dependent, endeavour to always know where the tonic is), Ed Sheeran, Family of the Year (Hero), Ivan & Alyosha, Nick Drake, Oasis, Radical Face, Tom Petty, Awol Nation. Also I suspect U2, Bob Dylan, Leonard Cohen, Randy Newman, and Tom Waits might be good. Essentially anything which is going to be I, IV, V dependent - or ‘to a large degree dependent’. This is one of those things in life where ‘more is more’ - the more you play things back by ear WITHOUT using any lead sheets or similar the better. More is more. At the beginning you will be fighting your way though each song, but after some practice you’ll start hearing: oh..I think that sounds like that other dominant, or sub-dominant. You’ll start hearing their relationships. Oh, one more thing. Play a tritone and listen to it. Dissonant right? It is not stable, it has a ratio of 45:32. If you’re talking about recognising Dominant chords which have a 3rd and a 7th then you’ll have this tritone. This is a good element to listen for which is not present in the Sub-Dominant.

It’s interesting how both IV and V can feel strongly as if they are leading back to I, and, that may be what you are feeling. Or, perhaps, you are thinking not of IV but of II6/5, which in C major is an F (IV) chord with a D added on the top. A II6/5 functions very much like a V, and is used that way in a lot of music. If one adds a G in the bass to the II6/5, one has a G7sus. People seem to vary in how they rationalize the phenomenon of dominance and tonality. My ear is probably not good enough to “think” in terms of scales that way. I do believe my ear “feels” two basic movements: V to I, outlined by the fifth in the base and the second (or third) in the upper voice; and, IV to I. In both cases, I “feel” the tonal motion downward (although the leading voice may move upward). They are two variations of a kind of coming to rest, in my mind. The V to I movement is somewhat more “final” in my mind, because, it doesn’t suggest anywhere else to go thereafter, perhaps (but, this is pure speculation on my part and not particularly thought through) it contains no descending half-step. The IV to I movement, on the other hand, has a noticeable, descending half-step from four to three. There’s a suggestion, in my mind at least, that the three might become the leading tone to the fourth, for example—that tonality is modulating to the IV as a new I. There’s another possibility about descending half-steps—they can function (especially in minor keys) to define a new, artificial (?) V on their destination. Typical case, perhaps: F to C, then E7 (B in the bass), then A-minor. The V-to-I movement doesn’t have either of these ambiguities, at least as I hear them.

‘Both the IV and V chords sound dominant to me. What are some tips to distinguish them in chord progressions?’ I actually don’t know what you are saying with this question, the IV & V chords can be easily distinguished by listening to them, and hearing them. A IV chord is 2 tones + one semitone away from the I chord, the V chord is two tones + one semitone + one tone away from the I chord. You can distinguish them from the number of intervals they are away from the home chord, the number of tones they are from the home chord. If we accept the I chord as being the ‘key’ then we count the intervals in that home key’s scale. I think it is important to focus on music in terms of how it sounds. I can always hear if a IVth or Vth interval is being used, your ear becomes accustomed to the intervals.

I agree with the other answers. Either you’re mistaken about what the IV and V chords are, or you don’t know what ‘dominant’ means in this context, or…you’re tone deaf. Whatever it is, there are no ‘tips’ to distinguish them, any more than there are tips to help people tell the difference between red and blue. You can either hear the difference between the dominant chord in a progression and the other chords, or you can’t.

One trick you can use while you’re practicing getting the difference down: IV-I is the textbook “plagal” cadence, which can be thought of as the “Amen” cadence:  Notice the tonic present in both chords. So, (as long as you’re certain it’s either either a IV or V chord) if you can sing the tonic with the chord, then it’s a IV chord. If the tonic clashes, it must be a V chord, because there’s no tonic present in a V triad.

In a 12 bar blues context, yes they are both dominant. Typically the IV chord is major in most nonblues compositions. The dominant 7th note of the IV chord is not part of major scale of a song’s key. For example, if you playing a tune in F, the IV chord is Bb. To make Bb chord dominant (in other words to make it a Bb7), you’ll need to add an Ab note to that Bb chord. That Ab note is not part of an F major scale.

The IV chord is a subdominant chord when used on a major scale. The characteristics of the IV chord contain the major 7th tone. The IV chord contains a b5 tone as a non-chord tone (tension) which can embellish the IV chord but lacks the dominant tri-tone punch. The IV chord resolves into the V chord and the V chord can stand alone or resolve into the I chord. The II chord and IV chords are both subdominant chords. They can be interchangeable at will. This where the II/V/I and the IV/V/I chord progressions are similar in cadence. The combination of the major 3rd and b7 tones (the tri-tone interval) produces the dominant chord sound. In the jazz minor scale, the IV chord contains a b7 tone as opposed to the major scale’s major 7th tone (labeled as a Lydian b7 chord). This could be a characteristic of the composer’s intent as to what scale type is being used or if the chord is “borrowed” from a different scale for effect. Good question. Thank you for asking!

I would suggest you play or listen to the I - IV - I cadence many times (also called the plagal cadence or “Amen”), and contrast that with playing/listening to the I - V - I cadence many times (often heard in the coda of first or last movements by Tchaikovsky or Beethoven, where they are repeated many times). I- IV-I has a peaceful quality, while the true dominant (V) is dynamic, dramatic and unstable.
The dominant (V) sounds five degrees above the tonic and the sub-dominant (IV) sounds five degrees below the tonic.
